blogs.author: Paul Graham
blogs.description: Lisp wizard and an investor. You should probably just google me.
blogs.title: Paul Graham

blogs.author: Jacob
blogs.description: I became financially independent at 30 and retired at 33. I blog about how to retire extremely early. A combination of simple living, anticonsumerism, DIY ethics, self-reliance, resilience, and applied capitalism
blogs.title: Early Retirement Extreme

blogs.author: Joel Spolsky
blogs.description: This is Joel on Software, where I’ve been ranting about software development, management, business, and the Internet since 2000. In 2000 I co-founded Fog Creek Software, where we created lots of cool things like the FogBugz bug tracker, Trello, and Glitch. I also worked with Jeff Atwood to create Stack Overflow and served as CEO of Stack Overflow from 2010-2019.
blogs.title: Joel on software

blogs.author: Linus Åkesson
blogs.description:
My name is Linus Åkesson, though some of you may know me as lft. I live in Lund, Sweden, and work as a software engineer. 
I dabble in many different areas. My blog is bilingual (swedish).
blogs.title: linusakesson

blogs.author: Julia Evans
blogs.description: I’m a software developer. I live in Montreal. I sometimes give talks. Most of my income comes from my programming zines business Wizard Zines.
blogs.title: jvns

blogs.author: Tim Urban, Andrew finn, Alicia mcelhone
blogs.description: Tim writes about his psychological shortcomings. Andrew writes about the business side. Alicia is the manager.
blogs.title: waitbutwhy

blogs.author: Sarah Perry, Kevin Simler, Joe Kelly, Carlos Bueno, Renee DiResta, and Taylor Pearson
blogs.description: Ribbonfarm is a longform blog devoted to unusual takes on both familiar and new themes. It was founded in 2007 by Venkatesh Rao, who serves as Editor-in-Chief
blogs.title: RibbonFarm

blogs.author: David Chapman
blogs.description: Meaningness is a hypertext book (in progress), plus a “metablog” that comments on it. The book begins with an appetizer. Alternatively, you might like to look at its table of contents, or some other starting points. Classification of pages by topics supplements the book and metablog structures.
blogs.title: meaningness

blogs.author: Gwern Branwen
blogs.description: I write about psychology, statistics, and technology; I am best known for work on the darknet markets & Bitcoin, blinded self-experiments & Quantified Self analyses, dual n-back & spaced repetition, and modafinil.
blogs.title: gwern

blogs.author: Scott Aaronson
blogs.description: A blog about wonky thinks like collapsing government, some opinions, quantum mechanics and computing.
blogs.title: scottaaronson

blogs.author: Idlewords
blogs.description: Interesting essays and interviews mostly political and meta.
blogs.title: Idlewords

blogs.author: Patrick Collison
blogs.description: I live in San Francisco and work at Stripe. I grew up in Ireland and previously studied math at MIT. I am on the boards of Stripe and the Long Now Foundation. (The long-term is underrated!)
blogs.title: Patrick Collison

blogs.author: Oona Räisänen
blogs.description: absorptions is a blog about my hobbies. So far it's mostly about signals, electronics and programming, but may pick up a random new field at any point. It's a place for me to direct my need to talk nerdy. Why? I like the smell of unsolved mysteries. Call them obsessions or special interests; I call them absorptions.
blogs.title: windytan

blogs.author: Alexey Guzey
blogs.description: I’m a researcher with background in Economics, Mathematics, and Cognitive Science. My biggest intellectual influences are Scott Alexander and Gwern. Right now, I think about meta-science, biology, and philanthropy. My long-term goal is to make the future humane, aesthetic, and to make it happen faster.
blogs.title: Alexey Guezy

blogs.author: Alex Tabarrok &  Tyler Cowen
blogs.description: Marginal Revolution is the blog of Tyler Cowen and Alex Tabarrok, both of whom teach at George Mason University. MR began in August of 2003 and there have been new posts daily since that time. In numerous reviews and ratings over the years Marginal Revolution has consistently been ranked as the best or one of the best economic blogs on the web, but it is more (and less) than that, also representing the quirks of its authors.
blogs.title: marginalrevolution

blogs.author: Jeff Preshing
blogs.description: This is where I write about programming-related stuff. I try to keep it technical, and tend to focus on C++ and Python, but these aren’t strict rules. You could say the main theme throughout this blog is a reverence and fascination for programming.
blogs.title: preshing

blogs.author: Eli Bendersky
blogs.description: This blog began in 2003 as a personal online journal; in the past few years it became mostly an outlet for technical, programming-related posts. It's my way to document things I find interesting for my future self.
blogs.title: Eli Bendersky's website

blogs.author: Glenn Engstrand
blogs.description: Whenever I evaluate a technology stack for microservice architecture viability, I implement the same feature identical polyglot persistent microservice then run it through the same load test as all the others. In that way, I can compare and contrast these various technology stacks. I blog about the results here.
blogs.title: Glenn Engstrand

blogs.author: Shane Mulligan
blogs.description: My journey into biosemiotics 🌻, xenolingustics 👽 and emacs 🐄
blogs.title: Bodacious Blog

blogs.author: Stavros Korokithakis
blogs.description: I figure some people might be interested in the projects I make from time to time, or the solution to problems I have, so I publish them.
blogs.title: Stavros' Stuff

blogs.author: Dave Glassanos
blogs.description: Non-technical advice to navigate your programming career.
blogs.title: Exponential Backoff

blogs.author: Christine Dodrill
blogs.description: Tech, Cooking, Linugistics, Programming language theory and more
blogs.title: Christine Dodrill

blogs.author: Soham Sankaran
blogs.description: Writing about humans, robots, and policy from an Indian startup founder, screenwriter, and recovering academic.
blogs.title: soham writes

blogs.author: Rohith Palakirti
blogs.description: I write a blog about deep learning and everything else that I'm in the process of learning.
blogs.title: Rohith's Blog

blogs.author: OldPanda
blogs.description: I shall dedicate myself to the interests of the country in life and death irrespective of personal weal and woe

blogs.description: Musings around the intersection of people and machines

blogs.author: Ibrahim Diallo
blogs.description: Telling stories about the programming world one statement at a time
blogs.title: Programming from the human perspective By Ibrahim Diallo

blogs.author: Devin Weaver (@sukima)
blogs.description: A blog of personal quality — I am a passionate software developer specialized in Ember.js, JavaScript, and Ruby. I dabble in Photography, 360 panoramic tours, interactive fiction, and geek culture.
blogs.title: TriTarget.org

blogs.author: Brajeshwar Oinam
blogs.description: I am a designer. I design experiences, opportunities, careers, teams, products, and organizations.
blogs.title: Brajeshwar Oinam

blogs.description: Software, programming, and maybe some powerlifting.
blogs.title: Blain Smith

blogs.author: Lukas Murdock
blogs.description: Designer, developer, and marketer trying to do work that matters for people who care.
blogs.title: Lukas Murdock

blogs.author: Matt Greer
blogs.description: I'm mostly a JavaScript developer who also has an interest in retro game tech. I tend to combine the two in various ways, such as modern web based tools for old game consoles.
blogs.title: Matt Greer

blogs.author: Franz Neubert
blogs.description: Software, projects & software projects. I write about personal projects and about things I learned at my job as a data engineer.
blogs.title: Franz Neubert: Writing
